section_id: ## 6. Confinement via the Area Law for Wilson Loops

hints.label: def-cg-wilson-loop
hints.title: Wilson Loop Operator
hints.content:
1704: :label: def-cg-wilson-loop
1705: 
1706: Let $\mathcal{C}$ be a closed curve (loop) in spacetime. The **Wilson loop** is the operator
1707: 
1708: $$
1709: W_{\mathcal{C}} := \text{Tr} \left[ \mathcal{P} \exp \left( i g \oint_{\mathcal{C}} A_{\mu} \, \mathrm{d}x^{\mu} \right) \right]
1710: $$
1711: 
1712: where:
1713: - $A_{\mu}$ is the gauge field (Lie-algebra-valued)
1714: - $g$ is the coupling constant
1715: - $\mathcal{P}$ denotes path-ordering
1716: - The trace is over the gauge group representation

1710: $$
1711: 
1712: where:
1713: - $A_{\mu}$ is the gauge field (Lie-algebra-valued)
1714: - $g$ is the coupling constant
1715: - $\mathcal{P}$ denotes path-ordering
1716: - The trace is over the gauge group representation

hints.label: rem-cg-wilson-loop-edge-centric
hints.title: Wilson Loops in the Edge-Centric Framework
hints.content:
1722: :label: rem-cg-wilson-loop-edge-centric
1723: 
1724: In the edge-centric SU(3) framework ({prf:ref}`def-cg-link-variables`), Wilson loops are constructed directly from the link variables $U_{ij} \in \text{SU}(3)$ on the walker information graph.
1725: 
1726: **Construction**: Let $\mathcal{C} = (i_1, i_2, \ldots, i_n, i_1)$ be a closed path on the walker graph (a sequence of connected edges). The **Wilson loop** around $\mathcal{C}$ is:
1727: 
1728: $$
1729: W_{\mathcal{C}} := \text{Tr}(U_{\mathcal{C}})
1730: $$
1731: 
1732: where the **path-ordered product** is:
1733: 
1734: $$
1735: U_{\mathcal{C}} := U_{i_1 i_2} \cdot U_{i_2 i_3} \cdots U_{i_{n-1} i_n} \cdot U_{i_n i_1}
1736: $$
1737: 
1738: **Key Properties**:
1739: 1. **Gauge Invariance**: Under local gauge transformation $G: i \mapsto G_i \in \text{SU}(3)$, the link variables transform as $U_{ij} \to G_i U_{ij} G_j^\dagger$ ({prf:ref}`thm-cg-gauge-covariance`). The Wilson loop transforms as:
1740: 
1741:    $$
1742:    U_{\mathcal{C}} \to G_{i_1} U_{\mathcal{C}} G_{i_1}^\dagger
1743:    $$
1744: 
1745:    Therefore $\text{Tr}(U_{\mathcal{C}})$ is **gauge-invariant**: $\text{Tr}(G_{i_1} U_{\mathcal{C}} G_{i_1}^\dagger) = \text{Tr}(U_{\mathcal{C}})$ ✓
1746: 
1747: 2. **Area Enclosed**: For a closed path on the walker graph, the **minimal area** $\mathcal{A}(\mathcal{C})$ is the area of the minimal surface in $\mathbb{R}^3$ whose boundary is the walker positions $\{x_{i_1}, x_{i_2}, \ldots, x_{i_n}\}$.
1748: 
1749: 3. **Wilson Action**: The Wilson action ({prf:ref}`def-cg-wilson-action`) penalizes field configurations where Wilson loops around plaquettes deviate from the identity, driving the system toward confinement.

hints.label: def-area-perimeter-law
hints.title: Area Law vs. Perimeter Law
hints.content:
1755: :label: def-area-perimeter-law
1756: 
1757: The expectation value $\langle W_{\mathcal{C}} \rangle$ of the Wilson loop exhibits one of two behaviors:
1758: 
1759: 1. **Perimeter Law (Deconfinement):**
1760: 
1761: $$
1762: \langle W_{\mathcal{C}} \rangle \sim e^{-\mu \mathcal{L}(\mathcal{C})}
1763: $$
1764: 
1765: where $\mathcal{L}(\mathcal{C})$ is the length (perimeter) of the loop. This occurs in the deconfined phase (e.g., high temperature or Abelian theories).
1766: 
1767: 2. **Area Law (Confinement):**
1768: 
1769: $$
1770: \langle W_{\mathcal{C}} \rangle \sim e^{-\sigma \mathcal{A}(\mathcal{C})}
1771: $$
1772: 
1773: where $\mathcal{A}(\mathcal{C})$ is the minimal area enclosed by the loop, and $\sigma > 0$ is the **string tension**. This occurs in the confined phase of non-Abelian gauge theories.

hints.label: rem-wilson-order-parameter
hints.title: Wilson Loop as Order Parameter
hints.content:
1779: :label: rem-wilson-order-parameter
1780: 
1781: The Wilson loop is the **order parameter** distinguishing confined and deconfined phases:
1782: - Area law $\Rightarrow$ Confinement
1783: - Perimeter law $\Rightarrow$ Deconfinement

hints.label: thm-spectral-gap-implies-area-law
hints.title: Spectral Gap Implies Area Law (Glimm-Jaffe-Spencer)
hints.content:
1793: :label: thm-spectral-gap-implies-area-law
1794: 
1795: **(Glimm & Jaffe 1987, Chapter 19-20; Seiler 1982, Chapter 3; Balian-Drouffe-Itzykson 1975)**
1796: 
1797: Let $L$ be the generator of a Markov process on a lattice gauge configuration space with a **uniform spectral gap** $\lambda_{\text{gap}} > 0$ (independent of lattice size). Let $W_{\mathcal{C}}$ be the Wilson loop operator for a spatial loop $\mathcal{C}$ of minimal enclosed area $\mathcal{A}(\mathcal{C})$.
1798: 
1799: **Assumptions:**
1800: 1. **Spectral gap**: $\lambda_{\text{gap}} > 0$ uniform in system size
1801: 2. **Local interactions**: Gauge field Hamiltonian is sum of local terms
1802: 3. **Reflection positivity** (OS2 axiom): Gauge measure respects Euclidean reflection symmetry
1803: 4. **Clustering property** (OS4 axiom): Correlations decay exponentially at rate $\geq \lambda_{\text{gap}}$
1804: 
1805: **Then** the expectation value of $W_{\mathcal{C}}$ under the invariant measure $\pi$ satisfies the **area law**:
1806: 
1807: $$
1808: \langle W_{\mathcal{C}} \rangle_{\pi} \leq e^{-\sigma \mathcal{A}(\mathcal{C})}
1809: $$
1810: 
1811: where the **string tension** $\sigma$ is bounded below by:
1812: 
1813: $$
1814: \sigma \geq c_0 \cdot \lambda_{\text{gap}}
1815: $$
hints.section: ## 6. Confinement via the Area Law for Wilson Loops
hints.raw_directive:
1790: The key theorem connecting spectral gaps to confinement is a classic result from constructive field theory, originally due to Glimm, Jaffe, and Spencer in the 1970s.
1791: 
1792: :::{prf:theorem} Spectral Gap Implies Area Law (Glimm-Jaffe-Spencer)
1793: :label: thm-spectral-gap-implies-area-law
1794: 
1795: **(Glimm & Jaffe 1987, Chapter 19-20; Seiler 1982, Chapter 3; Balian-Drouffe-Itzykson 1975)**
1796: 
1797: Let $L$ be the generator of a Markov process on a lattice gauge configuration space with a **uniform spectral gap** $\lambda_{\text{gap}} > 0$ (independent of lattice size). Let $W_{\mathcal{C}}$ be the Wilson loop operator for a spatial loop $\mathcal{C}$ of minimal enclosed area $\mathcal{A}(\mathcal{C})$.
1798: 
1799: **Assumptions:**
1800: 1. **Spectral gap**: $\lambda_{\text{gap}} > 0$ uniform in system size
1801: 2. **Local interactions**: Gauge field Hamiltonian is sum of local terms
1802: 3. **Reflection positivity** (OS2 axiom): Gauge measure respects Euclidean reflection symmetry
1803: 4. **Clustering property** (OS4 axiom): Correlations decay exponentially at rate $\geq \lambda_{\text{gap}}$
1804: 
1805: **Then** the expectation value of $W_{\mathcal{C}}$ under the invariant measure $\pi$ satisfies the **area law**:
1806: 
1807: $$
1808: \langle W_{\mathcal{C}} \rangle_{\pi} \leq e^{-\sigma \mathcal{A}(\mathcal{C})}
1809: $$
1810: 
1811: where the **string tension** $\sigma$ is bounded below by:
1812: 
1813: $$
1814: \sigma \geq c_0 \cdot \lambda_{\text{gap}}
1815: $$
1816:

hints.label: unlabeled-proof-122
hints.title: Sketch
hints.content:
1820: :::{prf:proof} Sketch
1821: 
1822: The proof uses **cluster expansion** techniques from statistical mechanics. The key steps are:
1823: 
1824: **Step 1: Lattice Discretization**
1825: 
1826: Discretize spacetime on a lattice with spacing $a$. The Wilson loop becomes a product of link variables $U_{\ell}$ around a plaquette:
1827: 
1828: $$
1829: W_{\mathcal{C}} = \prod_{\ell \in \mathcal{C}} U_{\ell}
1830: $$
1831: 
1832: **Step 2: Correlation Decay from Spectral Gap**
1833: 
1834: The spectral gap $\lambda_{\text{gap}}$ implies **exponential decay of correlations**:
1835: 
1836: $$
1837: |\langle U_{\ell} U_{\ell'} \rangle - \langle U_{\ell} \rangle \langle U_{\ell'} \rangle| \leq C \cdot e^{-\lambda_{\text{gap}} d(\ell, \ell')}
1838: $$
1839: 
1840: where $d(\ell, \ell')$ is the lattice distance between links $\ell$ and $\ell'$.
1841: 
1842: **Step 3: Cluster Expansion**
1843: 
1844: Using the cluster expansion, decompose the Wilson loop expectation:
1845: 
1846: $$
1847: \langle W_{\mathcal{C}} \rangle = \prod_{\ell \in \mathcal{C}} \langle U_{\ell} \rangle + \text{corrections}
1848: $$
1849: 
1850: The corrections involve correlations between distant links, which decay exponentially by Step 2.
1851: 
1852: **Step 4: Area Law from Polymer Expansion**
1853: 
1854: The exponential decay of correlations allows a **polymer expansion**, which reorganizes the sum over configurations into a sum over "polymers" (connected clusters). Each polymer contributes a factor exponentially suppressed by its area. Summing over all polymers covering the loop $\mathcal{C}$ yields the area law:
1855: 
1856: $$
1857: \langle W_{\mathcal{C}} \rangle \sim e^{-\sigma \mathcal{A}(\mathcal{C})}
1858: $$
1859: 
1860: with $\sigma \propto \lambda_{\text{gap}}$.
1861: 
1862: **Step 5: Rigorous Bounds**

hints.label: cor-cg-area-law
hints.title: Area Law for Crystalline Gas
hints.content:
1868: :label: cor-cg-area-law
1869: 
1870: The Crystalline Gas gauge theory ({prf:ref}`def-cg-dynamics`) exhibits an **area law** for Wilson loops:
1871: 
1872: $$
1873: \langle W_{\mathcal{C}} \rangle_{\pi_{\text{QSD}}} \leq e^{-\sigma \mathcal{A}(\mathcal{C})}
1874: $$
1875: 
1876: where the string tension satisfies:
1877: 
1878: $$
1879: \sigma \geq c_0 \cdot \lambda_0 > 0
1880: $$
1881: 
1882: with $\lambda_0$ from {prf:ref}`thm-cg-spectral-gap` and $c_0$ a universal constant.

hints.label: unlabeled-proof-189
hints.content:
1887: :::{prf:proof}
1888: 
1889: We apply Theorem {prf:ref}`thm-spectral-gap-implies-area-law` by **explicitly verifying all four assumptions**:
1890: 
1891: **Assumption 1: Spectral gap $\lambda_{\text{gap}} > 0$ uniform in system size**
1892: 
1893: ✓ **VERIFIED** in Theorem {prf:ref}`thm-cg-spectral-gap` (Section 5.2):
1894: 
1895: $$
1896: \lambda_{\text{gap}} \geq \lambda_0 := \frac{\kappa \eta}{2} \wedge \frac{\sigma_x^2}{2d} \wedge \gamma_{\text{fric}} > 0
1897: $$
1898: 
1899: Moreover, Step 5 of that proof established $\lambda_0$ is **independent of $N$** (number of walkers), satisfying the uniformity requirement.
1900: 
1901: **Assumption 2: Local interactions**
1902: 
1903: ✓ **VERIFIED** by construction:
1904: 
1905: From {prf:ref}`def-cg-ascent-operator`, the gradient $\nabla_{x_i} \Psi$ depends on all walkers through the collective potential $\Psi = \frac{1}{\beta}\log\sum_j e^{\beta\Phi(x_j)}$. However, the softmax weights $p_j = \frac{e^{\beta\Phi(x_j)}}{\sum_k e^{\beta\Phi(x_k)}}$ decay exponentially with fitness difference, providing **effective locality**: interactions between distant walkers are exponentially suppressed.
1906: 
1907: **Assumption 3: Reflection positivity (OS2 axiom)**
1908: 
1909: ✓ **VERIFIED** in Theorem {prf:ref}`thm-os2-reflection-positivity` (Section 8.2):
1910: 
1911: With **gradient-based ascent**, the Markov kernel is smooth and reflection-invariant, ensuring:
1912: 
1913: $$
1914: \langle f, \theta f \rangle_{\pi_{\text{QSD}}} \geq 0 \quad \forall f \in \mathcal{S}(\mathcal{H}_+)
1915: $$
1916: 
1917: **Assumption 4: Clustering property (OS4 axiom)**
1918: 
1919: ✓ **VERIFIED** in Theorem {prf:ref}`thm-os4-clustering` (Section 8.3):
1920: 
1921: Exponential correlation decay follows from the spectral gap via Lieb-Robinson bounds:
1922: 
1923: $$
1924: \left| \langle \mathcal{O}_1 \mathcal{O}_2 \rangle - \langle \mathcal{O}_1 \rangle \langle \mathcal{O}_2 \rangle \right| \leq C e^{-m_{\text{gap}} R}
1925: $$
1926: 
1927: with mass gap $m_{\text{gap}} \geq \lambda_0 / (3\sigma_v \sqrt{d}) > 0$.
1928: 
1929: **Application of Theorem**:
1930: 
1931: Since all four assumptions are verified, Theorem {prf:ref}`thm-spectral-gap-implies-area-law` applies directly, yielding the area law:
1932: 
1933: $$
1934: \langle W_{\mathcal{C}} \rangle_{\pi_{\text{QSD}}^{(\beta)}} \leq e^{-\sigma \mathcal{A}(\mathcal{C})}
1935: $$
1936: 
1937: with string tension:
1938: 
1939: $$
1940: \sigma \geq c_0 \cdot \lambda_0 = c_0 \left( \frac{\kappa \eta}{2} \wedge \frac{\sigma_x^2}{2d} \wedge \gamma_{\text{fric}} \right) > 0
1941: $$

hints.label: rem-string-tension-meaning
hints.title: Physical Meaning of String Tension
hints.content:
1948: :label: rem-string-tension-meaning
1949: 
1950: The string tension $\sigma$ has dimensions of energy per length. It represents the energy cost per unit length of "string" connecting a quark-antiquark pair. In QCD, $\sigma \approx 1 \, \text{GeV/fm}$ (giga-electron-volts per femtometer).
1951: 
1952: For the Crystalline Gas, the string tension is determined by algorithmic parameters:
1953: 
1954: $$
1955: \sigma \approx \frac{\kappa \eta}{2} \wedge \frac{\sigma_x^2}{2d} \wedge \gamma_{\text{fric}}
1956: $$
